title: To those who honestly don't think smurfing is a problem, click here.
body: Level 10-ish game, 1v2'd bot lane, but some of you have the audacity to say smurfing isn't an issue for new players? It completely ruins the learning curve for them.

replies.body:
I wonder how people like you survived when games didn't even have matchmaking. When you had to jump into a random server and there was about a 75% chance that at least two or three of the people you were playing with had played the game 10 times as long as you had and were vastly better than you on every single level. 

I think back to my days of playing Halo on PC, back in 2003 or so, where I would get my brains blown out from across the map by players with over a thousand hours using just the m6 pistol. 

And then I look at your posts, and I feel nothing.
Lvling up from lvls 1-30, half the time you're not playing vs new players. So this is really just fringed cases and mostly bronze-silvers lvling new accounts to "escape" elo hell.
You get better from playing against better opponents, so the idea that they miss out on learning is not true

> [{quoted}](name=WaffIeMaker,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=ZRkbFUnn,comment-id=0007,timestamp=2017-12-07T05:03:24.396+0000)
>
> You get better from playing against better opponents, so the idea that they miss out on learning is not true

That's very true, but only to some degree. While you do need to play against better opponents to improve, it needs to be gradual. If the skill gap between two players is too high, the guy getting smashed not only won't be able to learn as much since he'll literally get overwhelmed. But he might also get discouraged and literally give up. Players need to feel they stand a chance in order to have the will to improve. 

So actually, yes you can miss out on learning if you're only fighting people 5-6 times your skill level. It's why good matchmaking is so important in competitive games.
